questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have an Azure subscription that contains a virtual network named VNet1.

You need to implement hybrid connectivity between an on-premises network and VNet1. The solution must meet the following requirements:

• All cross-premises network traffic must traverse an ExpressRoute circuit.
• All cross-premises network traffic must be encrypted by using a Site-to-Site (S2S) VPN.

What should you include in the solution? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

comments.content:
Agree. This should be a s2s vpn connection over ER private peering solution. Advertise more specific prefixes on the VPN BGP session for the VPN-connected network.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/site-to-site-vpn-private-peering#routing

discussion.content: Private and more specific for the VPN. ExpressRoute is private only, not encrypted.
The same prefix for both connections.

comments.content: yeah, it could be, it seems a weird question anyway, maybe it misses a protocol/settings info statement in the questions...

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Both answer is VNet1,VNet2,VNet3

As per https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-about-point-to-site-routing#multis2s to access Virtual Networks that are connected to another Virtual Network using S2S VPN, BGP must be used.

Therefore, only VNET 1 and VNET 2 are accessible by both Windows AND Non-Windows clients.

VNet1 and VNet2 only, S2S does not support OpenVPN. 
Answer is B for both.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have an Azure subscription that contains the virtual networks shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You have devices that run either Windows or macOS. The devices connect to VGW1 by using the OpenVPN protocol.

Which virtual networks can each device access? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

//IMG//

You have an Azure subscription that contains the resources shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You plan to deploy an Azure Virtual Network NAT gateway named Gateway1. The solution must meet the following requirements:

• VM1 will access the internet by using its public IP address.
• VM2 will access the internet by using its public IP address.
• Administrative effort must be minimized.

You need to ensure that you can deploy Gateway1 to Vnet1.

What is the minimum number of subnets that Vnet1 must have?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Cannot deploy in GatewaySugnet, and if deployed in Subnet1 or Subnet2 VM1 or VM2 will start accessing the Internet by using the NAT GW IP address. Thus, a new subnet (4th) is needed.

comments.content:
But NAT gateway cannot be used with Basic SKU public IP addresses. 
"Basic resources, such as basic load balancer or basic public IPs aren't compatible with NAT gateway. NAT gateway can't be used with subnets where basic resources exist. Basic load balancer and basic public IP can be upgraded to standard to work with a NAT gateway."

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/nat-gateway/nat-overview

Does it change the answer to 3 ?

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/nat-gateway/nat-overview
A NAT gateway can’t be deployed in a gateway subnet.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Cannont deploy Nat gatway in GatewaySubnet and in subnet where basic resource exists. therefore we need another subnet

comments.content: You can still deploy it to Subnet2, which has a VM with a Standard IP and not set it up to manage the IP of the VM. No need to create a new subnet in this scenario

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
NAT gateway can't be used with subnets where basic resources exist.
A NAT gateway can’t be deployed in a gateway subnet.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/nat-gateway/nat-overview

Selected Answer: B
• Since VM1 and VM2 will retain their public IPs, NAT Gateway will not manage their outbound traffic.
• No additional subnets are required to deploy the NAT Gateway.
• Therefore, VNet1 only needs 3 subnets: Subnet1, Subnet2, and the existing GatewaySubnet.

Selected Answer: C
Actually since we can't associate the NAT Gateway to any of the other three subnets, then a fourth subnet is required.

Selected Answer: B
NAT gateway doesn't require a subnet itself, only require a subne to be associated with. So the answer is 3

comments.content:
I'm not so good with Spanish I'll try with English :-)
You need a 4th subnet because if you connect NAT gateway with the subnet 1-2 the VMs will use the public IP of the NAT gateway.
you can't attach a NAT gateway to a Gatewaysubnet too, so you need a fourth subnet.
read this
""The NAT gateway takes precedence over a load balancer, regardless of the outbound rules. The gateway also takes precedence over public IP addresses that are assigned directly to VMs.""
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/architecture/networking/guide/well-architected-network-address-translation-gateway#operational-excellence

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Yo solo veo que necesitemos 3 subredes no entiendo porque necesitaríamos una 4a Subnet1 y Subnet2 son necesarias para hospedar VM1 y VM2, respectivamente, cada una con su propia dirección IP pública. GatewaySubnet es necesaria para implementar la puerta de enlace NAT. Cual seria la 4 ???

Answer is correct - IKEDiagnosticLog

IKEDiagnosticLog = The IKEDiagnosticLog table offers verbose debug logging for IKE/IPsec. This is very useful to review when troubleshooting disconnections, or failure to connect VPN scenarios.

GatewayDiagnosticLog = Configuration changes are audited in the GatewayDiagnosticLog table.

TunnelDiagnosticLog = The TunnelDiagnosticLog table is very useful to inspect the historical connectivity statuses of the tunnel.

RouteDiagnosticLog = The RouteDiagnosticLog table traces the activity for statically modified routes or routes received via BGP.

P2SDiagnosticLog = The last available table for VPN diagnostics is P2SDiagnosticLog. This table traces the activity for Point to Site.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/troubleshoot-vpn-with-azure-diagnostics
I = I for remembering
correct Answer
correct

A.
If the IPsec tunnel fails to establish, Azure will keep retrying every few seconds. For this reason, troubleshooting "VPN down" issues is very convenient on IKEdiagnosticLog because you do not have to wait for a specific time to reproduce the issue.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/troubleshoot-vpn-with-azure-diagnostics#IKEDiagnosticLog

If you have trouble remembering this question and you start to think the answer is TunnelDiagnosticLog, then you need to remember to tunnel deeper - as the answer is IKEDiagnosticLog. Although it is very easy to immediately see the word tunnel thinking it may be the right answer.

Selected Answer: A
A.
https://docs.microsoft.com/es-es/azure/vpn-gateway/troubleshoot-vpn-with-azure-diagnostics

Selected Answer: A
A. IKEDiagnosticLog

Selected Answer: A
IKEDiagnosticLog
Correct
Yeah, that's the most detailed log. The only that would help you troubleshooting the most common issue - IKE errors.

correct !
The IKEDiagnosticLog table offers verbose debug logging for IKE/IPsec. This is very useful to review when troubleshooting disconnections, or failure to connect VPN scenarios.

questions.question_text:
You fail to establish a Site-to-Site VPN connection between your company's main office and an Azure virtual network.
You need to troubleshoot what prevents you from establishing the IPsec tunnel.
Which diagnostic log should you review?

comments.content: You can't resize the VNET as it is in use.

discussion.content:
I think the given answer it's correct:
-1 Resize Vnet1 (for example to 10.0.1.0/24 so we don't need NAT rules)
-2 Create local gw
-3 Add connection
-4 Azure extended network

1. Resize to VGW1 to VpnGw2 or higher 
2. Create Local GW 
3. Create NAT rules 
4. Add a connection

Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/nat-howto#part-1-create-vnet-and-gateways

- Azure VPN Gateway NAT supports the scenario to connect on-premises networks or branch offices to an Azure virtual network with overlapping IP addresses. 
- NAT is supported on the following SKUs: VpnGw2~5, VpnGw2AZ~5AZ.
Correct answer should be:
1- Resize VGW1
2- On VGW1, Configure Local network gateway
3- on VGW1, add a connection
4- On VGW1, add Nat rules
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/nat-overview

comments.content:
Your answer is almost correct, the order is
- Resize VGW1 because only VpnGW2 VpnGw5, VpnGw2AZ-5AZ allow for NAT rules
- On VGW1, create a local gateway
- On VGW1, add NAT rules
- On VGW1, add a connection
A note in https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/nat-howto#part-1-create-vnet-and-gateways clear states that the note should be the last step

discussion.content:
I think any answer that involves resizing the VNet is too much admin effort. Instead, its:
1. Resize VGW1 (Upgrade to at least VpnGw2 to enable NAT support.)
2. On VGW1, create a local gateway (Defines the on-premises network in Azure.)
3. On VGW1, add a connection (Establishes the Site-to-Site VPN tunnel.)
4. On VGW1, add NAT rules (Resolves overlapping IP conflicts.)

comments.content:
1. On VGW1, create a local gateway
2. On VGW1, add NAT rules
3. On VGW1, add a connection
4. Configure an Azure extended network.
Resize Vnet will affect existing resource, like VM and gateway subnet. NAT rules must be created before creating connections
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/nat-howto

2. On VGW1 create LGW
3. add NAT

-2 Create local gw

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
1.On VGW1, create a local gateway.
2.On VGW1, add a connection.
3.On VGW1, add NAT rules.
4.Configure an Azure extended network

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

You have 100 on-premises servers with IP addresses from the 10.0.0.0/24 IP address space.

You have an Azure subscription that contains a virtual network named VNet1, an Azure VPN gateway named VGW1, and 100 virtual machines. VNet1 has an IP address space of 10.0.0.0/22. VGW1 uses the VpnGw1 SKU.

You need to ensure that the Azure virtual machines and the on-premises servers can communicate by using VGW1. The solution must minimize administrative effort.

Which four actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.

//IMG//
